Award.AwardTitle: Probing the Structure-property Relationship of Core/Shell Bimetal Nanoparticles as a Model Catalyst

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract

Technical Impact

The combination of two metals to make a bimetallic catalyst frequently leads to a more catalytically active material than either constituent metal. Besides higher activities, bimetallic catalysts can have improved selectivities and greater deactivation resistance. The catalytic chemistry that explains how bimetallic enhancement arises is not well explained. Depending on the chemical reaction, the enhancement can be attributed to a geometric effect, an electronic effect, or a mixed metal site effect. The difficulties in determining the source of catalytic enhancement are numerous: enhancement could be due to a combination of these effects; the bimetallic nanostructure is not well-controlled at the synthesis level; there may be a metal-support interaction; or the studied bimetallic nanostructure can reconfigure during the chemical reaction.

So, how to develop a greater understanding of bimetallic catalysts so that they may be exploited appropriately is a significant question. Professor Michael Wong at William Marsh Rice University in Houston has an approach to developing more of this understanding. Wong intends to focus on a model of a bimetallic catalyst in which metallic nanoparticles of one metal are the support for the second active metal. The interaction is built-in and controllable, and amenable to the analysis of the bimetallic nanostructure using spectroscopic methods near reaction conditions; and culminating in the quantification of their catalytic properties under reaction conditions that do not modify the nanostructure. The model system is based on previous studies using palladium metal supported on gold nanoparticles, and the model test reaction is the catalysis in the water phase of trichloroethene hydrodechlorination.

Continued innovations in catalysis technology rely on the development of novel materials and the rigorous elucidation of reactivity dependence on catalyst nanostructure.PdAu bimetallic catalysis has shown some promise as a new technology for water-phase hydrodechlorination. This technology is important for pollution control in groundwater, a source for >50% of US drinking water.

Broader Impact

This proposal describes a three-year research and teaching plan consisting of multidisciplinary training of graduate and undergraduate students in materials chemistry, heterogeneous catalysis, chemical engineering fundamentals, and colloid science. Three new educational and community outreach activities are proposed: a yearly NanoDays demonstration at the Children's Museum of Houston, a local-area high school teachers development program in coordination with the NSF-sponsored RET program at Rice, and a lab module design project incorporated into the graduate-level kinetics/reactor engineering course. This award is being funded jointly by the CBET Catalysis and Biocatalysis Program and the CHE Catalysis Program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project focused on understanding more clearly the enhancement sources in bimetallic catalysis, through the synthesis of model bimetal nanoparticles in which one metal is the "active" phase and the second metal is the "non-active" phase; the analysis of the bimetal nanostructure using spectroscopic methods near reaction conditions; and quantification of their catalytic properties under reaction conditions that do not modify the nanostructure.

 

Intellectual Merit:

We developed Au nanoparticles decorated with controlled amounts of Pd metal (Pd-on-Au NPs) as our model catalyst, and established a number of interesting catalytic and structural features. The Au nanoparticle diameter affected the catalytic activity for trichloroethene hydrodechlorination (TCE HDC), due to differences in Pd surface speciation. Pd-on-Au NPs contain Pd surface ensembles that are surprisingly stable to temperatures as high as ~250 °C. Pd metal is susceptible to becoming partially oxidized under oxidative reaction conditions, except when Pd is supported on Au NP surfaces. Au stabilizes the supported Pd metal from over-oxidizing, leading to more catalytically stable metal active sites. Originally conceived to have enhanced reduction capabilities, Pd-on-Au NPs also have enhanced oxidation catalysis properties: they have the deactivation resistance of Au and high oxidation activity of Pd.

Many chemical reactions follow a volcano-shape dependence on Pd surface coverage, suggesting a general characteristic of this catalyst structure. Reactions include perchloroethene and chloroform HDC, nitrophenol and nitrite anion hydrogenation, and glycerol and methyl glucuronide partial oxidation. Maximum activity commonly occurs at a Pd content of ~50-60% surface coverage, and nominally 10× more active than monometallic Pd. An alumina-supported PdAu catalyst synthesized to have a Pd-on-Au bimetallic structure is more active than alumina-supported monometallic Pd, as demonstrated at the lab-scale, via continuous-flow HDC of chloroform-containing groundwater. Eighteen days of operation was possible with periodic regeneration using dilute bleach.

Synthesis studies carried in this project led to plasmonically-active rod-shaped Au NPs that can be photothermally heated to accelerate the catalytic activity of surface-bound thermophilic enzymes. The enzymatic activity can be increased by 60% after shining with visible light, with minimal heating of the bulk water reaction medium. The metal-on-metal nanoparticle structural concept was extended to In-on-Pd NPs, targeted for the possible study of nitrate anion hydrogenation.

 

Broader Impact:

Pd-on-Au NPs are highly active for a number of water-phase chemical reactions, including those leading to clean water. Many water-contaminating compounds are toxic and carcinogenic, and they generally cannot be removed effectively using the conventional methods of carbon adsorption and air-stripping. Catalysis can be the basis of a new water treatment approach, especially for recalcitrant pollutants. The metal-on-metal synthesis route may be extendable to many other metal combinations, with the additional benefits of independent control of the support particle size and of the surface coverage of the second metal. This synthesis approach is amenable to high-throughput generation of catalyst libraries. This project contributed to the education and training of three graduate students, of whom two are female. Twelve published papers, one book chapter, two PhD theses, one poster presentation, and twenty-five invited presentations resulted.


Last Modified: 12/05/2017
Modified by: Michael Wong
